June 2, 1944
Dear Family,
This must be an entirely off-the-record account of a "Journey
Among Warriora" which must have no publicity because of rules and
regulations laid down by Security Control Officers.
Of course the route
which I followed has been described - complete with photographs - in
other nagarines but it must nevertheless not be made publie.
I would like to have written the story and sent it home from time to time
as a play by play account but the censors will not pass any letter
nore informative or exciting than one of those juvenile masterpieces which
good out *pear Dedin
How are you?
I am fine.
I am having an awfully
good time, etc.,
You can't even fall back on that much over worked
topic of
weather for even the weather is secret.
Therefore, this report
had to be written after my return.
I often wonder if the Security Control
Officials - most of whom are secure anough in Washington - have not brought
about as many casualities as ther - and as much expense - through silly
blackout regulations, sir raid shelters, camoflaged buildings etc, ete.
The drole side of their activities is the fact that the nearer you get to
the fighting front the less "security".
For example, it takes lote of time
and much showing of credentials to get into the Army or lavy building in
Washington,
but I strolled into General Chenault's headquarters along with
coolies and anyone else who wanted to go without even a challenge.
we wish to vire Washington the departure time of a transatlantic Clipers -
(known only to come 200,000 people to see the take-off) the message must
be sent in code, but when we dispaten 20 planes over the Japanese lines the
the message is sent in plain English.
*ll I suppose that is all a part of
war and I'll now get along with the story.
After a flight pam New York, I left Miani by regular PAA commer-
cial schedule on Tuesday,
l8th, and flee over the blue waters of the
Caribbean to Cuba, where we landed at Canaguay,
then on across Guantanamo Bay
at the eastern part of the island (which unbeknowst to many is as much
American territory as 1o Wichita, Kansas) on to Port au Prince,
capital of
Then a landing at Cludad
Trujillo in the Dominican Republic, where
Columbus sleeps in the first cathedral of the Western Hemisphere.
overnight stop was San Juen.
afternoon,
where we arrived on schedule late in the
The following day,
Wednesday, I motored 70 miles through the
to Borinquen (Arm") Fiold to wait there for a CNAC delivery flight.
(New GNAC ships are flow? tr. China by pilots at the end of their home leave).
The life of Puerto
Rico is so similar
to the Philippines as to be startling.
No doubt this is due to the ipanish influence for Spain lost both islands
to us in 1893.
Another factor is the economy-sugar is the predominant
crop, with rice, tobacco and coconut producte.
The following day, Thursday fly 20th,
the CNAC C-47 (like a DC-3
orily with bucket seats along each side of the cabin) arrived from Miami and
we departed early Friday morning, following the islands wich run all the
coast of South America.
It is a beautiful flight starting with
